1.text: I’m a solicitor and mediator at Alternative Family Law.

4.text: I’m also the author of a textbook on civil partnership.

8.text: Today I want to talk to you about why civil partnership is not the same as marriage

13.text: for same-sex couples and why it is still discriminatory.

18.text: Tony graduated in the mid-70s and became a teacher.

22.text: From the beginning he jointed the teachers’ pension scheme.

24.text: He met Robert in 1985 and they have been together since.

29.text: In 2005 Tony and Robert registered a civil partnership.

34.text: For all their friends and family this was a wedding.

39.text: Tony plans to retire from teaching in 2013 at the age of 60.

43.text: He will then receive his teacher’s pension.

45.text: If Tony dies before Robert, Robert will get a dependent’s pension based on 25 years

52.text: of service from 1988-2013, which is about 15% of Tony’s final salary.

59.text: If, however, Tony had married Rowena and was going to die before her in exactly the same scenario,

66.text: she would get about 22% of his final salary as a pension for 35 years from 1978

78.text: So that’s a pension that’s almost 50% more than the one Robert will get.

85.text: Tony paid exactly the same contributions into his pension scheme as all his male colleagues;

88.text: and it made no difference that he was gay. He didn’t save, he paid the same contributions

94.text: But because he is gay and he’s in a civil partnership to another man that man,

99.text: if he survives Tony, gets a lower pension than the widows of his colleagues.

106.text: Teresa and Sally are retired and they are moving to Portugal where they have bought

112.text: a house where they will live in their retirement.

115.text: Now Portugal recognises same-sex marriage and same-sex couples can get married in Portugal.

121.text: However, Portugal does not recognise a UK civil partnership as a same-sex marriage there.

127.text: So if one of them dies before the other, then potentially in Portugal there would be death

135.text: duties to pay on the house.

138.text: And that is simply because the civil partnership is not recognised as a marriage in Portugal.

143.text: Teresa may have to sell the house to pay the death duties and end up homeless.

148.text: If Theresa and Sally could get married in England, then of course it would be recognised.

153.text: Of course these are only 2 examples of very specific cases, but they are actually taken

158.text: from real cases in real life.

162.text: On an everyday basis, of course, lesbian and gay couples up and down the country have to

168.text: identify themselves as lesbian or gay

170.text: and out themselves when they tick a box saying “civil partnership” on any official form.

175.text: Some forms have a combined box for “civil partners/married”,

177.text: but there is no requirement for that to be so

182.text: and the boxes can be separate.

185.text: And for some things, as we have seen for pensions, it does matter.

188.text: That is like saying: “Are you married to somebody of a different skin colour or religion?”

195.text: which you are not asked on any official forms.

199.text: Equally these things can attract discrimination and disapproval by some people.

204.text: If you agree that marriage should be open to all, including same-sex couples, then please

208.text: go on the website of the

210.text: Coalition for Equal Marriage c4em.org.uk and sign the petition there.
